paragraphs.name: 9c90
paragraphs.text: On Survival

paragraphs.name: 6c43
paragraphs.text: Transcript from the Nordic by Nature Podcast — Aug. 22nd, 2019

creator.name: Daniel Christian Wahl
creator.bio: Catalysing transformative innovation, cultural co-creation, whole systems design, and bioregional regeneration. Author of Designing Regenerative Cultures

paragraphs.name: d49e
paragraphs.text: The Extinction Rebellion Logo — a call for radical action.

paragraphs.name: 9c90
paragraphs.text: On Survival

paragraphs.name: 6c43
paragraphs.text: Transcript from the Nordic by Nature Podcast — Aug. 22nd, 2019

paragraphs.name: 52dd
paragraphs.text:
Nordic by Nature Podcast - Out now!
Direct Link to Transistor: https://share.transistor.fm/s/51f13fa5 Nordic by Nature is a new type of mindful and…www.imaginarylife.net

paragraphs.name: d1b1
paragraphs.text: My name is Daniel Wahl. I used to be a marine biologist, got disheartened with reductionist science and lack of including other ways of knowing into the way we do science, and ended up doing a Masters in Holistic Science at Schumacher college.

paragraphs.name: 5d30
paragraphs.text: At that point, I realised the power of design in putting this new holistic world view of Gaia theory and Goethean and Holistic Science into action, and have been on this path exploring how we can redesign the human presence and impact on earth within our lifetime, so we can actually have a future as a species, because we are currently facing the possibility of short term human extinction, if we don’t fundamentally change our ways.
Life is a planetary process. And we are part of that planetary process.

paragraphs.name: e819
paragraphs.text: I work a lot now with the term regenerative design and regenerative development.

paragraphs.name: af75
paragraphs.text: Sustainable being something that is really about ways of doing things that don’t add any more damage to the system.

paragraphs.name: 6e84
paragraphs.text: And restorative and regenerative, going beyond that, and actually trying to undo the damage that we’ve done over so many decades and centuries of very unsustainable practices.

paragraphs.name: 9db5
paragraphs.text: So, it’s very much about finding solutions that come out of ‘place.’

It is about attuned to the story that the place itself wants to tell, and the people who have lived with it for generations. But it also is central that it’s about enabling their capacity — of the people who actually live in that place to respond to change as it is inevitable.

paragraphs.name: 236f
paragraphs.text: My belief is that design has a huge part in making that possible.

paragraphs.name: 5fb2
paragraphs.text: Well, the process of the United Nations responding to climate change has been painfully slow.

paragraphs.name: b69c
paragraphs.text: With the Paris breakthrough, there’s been some form of commitment of staying under two degrees average warming globally. But more recently the IPCC has revised that, and has said that it’s necessary to actually stay below one point five degrees. The reality is we’re not on track at all.

paragraphs.name: d4c3
paragraphs.text: We’re on track to six seven eight degrees warming which basically would mean the unravelling of ecosystems around the globe and the end of civilization as we know it.

paragraphs.name: cf0c
paragraphs.text: In the most recent report — actually it was November 2018 — the IPCC gave the world 12 years to fundamentally respond to this crisis. But I think that again the IPCC has a tendency to be conservative, so they don’t get criticized. And 12 years is too long of a window of opportunity to give ourselves.

paragraphs.name: 336d
paragraphs.text: I think Antonio Guterres the Secretary General of the U.N. in September last year was probably more on the mark by saying that if we don’t respond within the next two or three years, in the way that is unprecedented in terms of international collaboration, then we might have triggered runaway climate change to a point that even if we decide afterwards to do something about it, it would be too late.

paragraphs.name: 020f
paragraphs.text: We don’t even know half or more than half of the species yet that exist. Particularly the species in the soil, the microbes. We’re just at the beginning of cataloguing them all.

paragraphs.name: 4ecb
paragraphs.text: And really that’s where soil fertility starts, and with it the foundations for higher lifeforms.

paragraphs.name: c3aa
paragraphs.text: It’s really understanding that every single species does matter and has a role to play in creating this collaborative symbiotic system that is basically life as a planetary process.

paragraphs.name: 4acb
paragraphs.text:
And we’re part of it, and we’re completely dependent on it.
 — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — -

paragraphs.name: 5caf
paragraphs.text: I strongly believe in the power of design.

I think ultimately, it’s about design as human intentionality expressed through interactions and relationships. It covers product design but it also covers other more complex issues like monetary systems, transport systems, our whole economic system and even the way we do research in the different academic disciplines.

paragraphs.name: d97f
paragraphs.text: There’s a design decision at the beginning of each discipline. So, basically any act human intention has a design element in it.

paragraphs.name: 82b1
paragraphs.text: In that sense, the most powerful design intervention is the meta design intervention of changing people’s world views and value systems, and the stories we tell about each other and in our relationship to nature. When you shift that then our perceived and our real needs shift.
And with that our intention shifts in everything down stream changes.

paragraphs.name: 3b1c
paragraphs.text: I think design is powerful and designers very often oversell it, and most design schools still haven’t actually woken up to how critical design and deep ecological design thinking could be to the survival of our species.

paragraphs.name: 00a1
paragraphs.text: There are a lot of companies out there who are supplying things we don’t really need or they’re supplying them in a way that is based on programmed obsolescence and turnover of products.

paragraphs.name: b731
paragraphs.text: And I don’t think that that kind of business practice has a future.

paragraphs.name: f74b
paragraphs.text: I think we need to create much more durable products that much more easily repairable at a local level.

paragraphs.name: eb75
paragraphs.text: But we also need to create products that are to some extent, the components are more recyclable. But really if you go deeper, you realize that most of the materials we make things out of, we’re going to run out of sooner or later.

paragraphs.name: e913
paragraphs.text: So, all that thinking around Circular Economy and two loops in the Circular Economy diagram with a cradle to cradle diagram, the industrial metabolism and the biological metabolism, they’re really just concepts.

paragraphs.name: 6d30
paragraphs.text: Ultimately, we’re going to have to shrink the industrial metabolism because most of the materials in that cycle we won’t be able to recycle forever.

paragraphs.name: ac67
paragraphs.text: So, one of the big oversells around that is this concept of upcycling. It doesn’t actually work to up cycle things indefinitely, unless you have a free source of energy and there is no such thing.

paragraphs.name: 934c
paragraphs.text: We’re really needing to fundamentally shift our material culture towards more bio-materials that are regenerative grown, in the region, for the region, and based on the resources that that particular ecosystem has to offer.

paragraphs.name: f279
paragraphs.text: It has to be done in such a way that it doesn’t destroy the rest of the ecosystem. So, the contrary, it has to be done in a way that it regenerates the ecosystem.
Basically, these companies are beholden to their shareholders. They operate within a system that is fundamentally exploitative and degenerative. That system is our current economic system.

paragraphs.name: c028
paragraphs.text: The way that we’ve designed money and the way money is created and the way that we have differential interests on deposit and loans and therefore create an economic playing field that is based on a zero-sum thinking — basically on winners and losers. We have a system like that, and we have that necessity that a national economy needs to grow at a minimum at 3 percent per annum otherwise it collapses,

paragraphs.name: 763e
paragraphs.text: There are a lot of top-level sustainability minded CEOs that really do care, and yet they are stuck in a system where to some extent, most of what they do is moving deck chairs on the Titanic.

paragraphs.name: d184
paragraphs.text: Ultimately, they really need to consider that maybe the assumption that these companies, just because they’ve been around for 100 years, have to be around for another hundred years, might be an erroneous assumption.

paragraphs.name: 3ac4
paragraphs.text: Maybe some of these companies actually have to program for their own end or design for their own death in ways that they can then re-emerge like a phoenix from the ashes, as knowledge networks that help more regional production and regional consumption [00:09:39] They could contribute in innovation and development that they’ve been very good at.

paragraphs.name: a14d
paragraphs.text: But for a lot of people who are working in these companies things are changing fast. They are beginning to see that their children are not going to school on Fridays because they’re claiming their right to a Liveable Future. Or they see London being disrupted by the Extinction Rebellion and more and more people getting more and more verbal about the fact that it’s five past 12.

paragraphs.name: ecd3
paragraphs.text: We don’t even have a guarantee that we are still going to be able to make it if we do things fundamentally different now.

paragraphs.name: 4d0d
paragraphs.text: Most people today are still somewhat stuck — realizing how profound the changes are that we are now called to do individually, as communities, as nations, and as one human family. And at the same time, it is understandable that we want to make sure our kids are in school, and that we can pay the bills, and food is on the table.

paragraphs.name: f9f3
paragraphs.text: [We are constantly navigating the dilemma between transformative and incremental innovation in response to these converging crises.]

paragraphs.name: 1fe8
paragraphs.text: We are facing transformative change in a way that incremental innovations, and incremental changes, just aren’t going to respond to in time. So, hold onto your hats!

paragraphs.name: 74ff
paragraphs.text: We have to relearn how to collaborate [to make it through the eye of the needle].

paragraphs.name: ea4c
paragraphs.text: Moving from competitive advantage to collaborative advantage. And realizing that we’re all in this together. Living Spaceship Earth is in danger of collapsing on us.

paragraphs.name: 36c5
paragraphs.text:
We’re living in a dream-nightmare, that tells the story that we are somehow separate from nature — that culture and nature are not one. [This is one of the fundamental epistemological and ontological fallacies of our time.]
 — — — — — — — — — — — — — –
I’m increasingly thinking that by working bioregionally we are working at the scale at which we can make the biggest difference.

Bioregionalism has been around since the late 1960s. The central concept is re-habitation: re-inhabiting our bioregions, and reconnecting to the biological cycles, the ecological cycles of those regions.

paragraphs.name: 9f63
paragraphs.text: Bioregional thinking is increasingly affecting the conversation about what sustainable cities might look like. We have to understand that it is about a reconnection of the city back to its region. I could definitely see that there could be new examples of this developed in Sweden.

paragraphs.name: 9f0e
paragraphs.text: It’s the same with a lot of regions that people have strong allegiance to their particular region.

paragraphs.name: db73
paragraphs.text: And so, I think that’s a great starting point because one of the core things about regenerative development and creating regenerative cultures is that they are born out of the uniqueness — the bio cultural uniqueness — of place.

They are sensitive to both the ecological and biological uniqueness of the ecosystems they inhabit, but they also are sensitive to the historical cultural dimension, of how people have lived in relationship with nature, and with the elements and with climate, and with the patterns of that particular place.

I think it makes a lot of sense to rekindle those regional identities, but not to do so in a parochial “Let’s go back and pull up the draw bridges, and create lifeboats in a turbulent world” kind of way. Rather, by understanding that the bioregion is the scale of action for a globally collaborative effort to heal the planet — that we have raped and pillaged. In doing so we can possibly also heal ourselves, heal our relationship to each other and heal the relationship between humanity and nature.

paragraphs.name: c4f1
paragraphs.text: I know that in Costa Rica there’s a movement to create a bioregional regenerative development case study in one part of the country. And actually the whole country is looking at adopting regenerative development as their main development strategy and working on a Regenerative Road Map [in partnership with Common Earth, and organisation that was tasked by the Commonwealth Secretariat to support the development of such road maps for all the 53 nations of the Commonwealth.]

Things are shifting! 
 — — — — — — — — — — — — — –
Luckily, I also see that there’s a confluence of movements in all walks of life like people trying to transform business from within.

paragraphs.name: b8e1
paragraphs.text: In recent years the Capital Institute started initiatives to work with people in regions to create these “regen” economy hubs at the bioregional scale.

paragraphs.name: dd29
paragraphs.text: This movement is growing and the different players are still not necessarily fully aware of each other’s good work. [This is where part of my work comes in: to make the emerging new system more connected to itself and aware of itself; to make the ReGeneration rising visible and weave alliances and partnerships for collaborative advantage; to heal the Earth and her people, place by place, community by community, bioregion by bioregion.]

I’m also thinking of the Planetary Health Alliance with network of universities and research institutions around the world doing the research and looking into the connections between planetary health, ecosystems health, population health, and individual health. [I wrote my PhD on Design for Human and Planetary Health in 2006, long before that alliance was started.]

paragraphs.name: 8ab9
paragraphs.text: We need to really understand the intrinsic value of all life and the value of planetary health to the whole community of life.

paragraphs.name: 66e6
paragraphs.text: … and then there are organizations like Commonland in the Netherlands who’ve developed functional strategies to do large scale ecosystems restoration, working with local farmers, and local landowners, in specific areas around the world, and transforming entire regions that are between 500,000 and a million hectares in size — regeneration at the landscape scale.
The momentum is building!

paragraphs.name: e6f6
paragraphs.text: I think the next two years are critical. I’m still hopeful.

paragraphs.name: eb84
paragraphs.text: We are actually going to see this transformative change to become a global emergency response.

paragraphs.name: 11a1
paragraphs.text: It’s only now that we’re slowly beginning to link up the people who have pioneered work on sustainable cities and sustainable architecture and in bio-materials based construction methodologies and so forth. We are seeing pioneering work in buy materials and product design. There are people doing wonderful work of Earth care and earth healing — ecotherapy — from permaculture to agroforestry to analogue forestry and all these other techniques that have been around for a while and have been improved over years and years of experimenting.

paragraphs.name: 74d8
paragraphs.text: We also have lots of case studies to point out that we can if we choose to have a positive impact on the environment that we inhabit. There are plenty of places around the world where large scale regenerative agricultural projects have shown impressive ways what can be achieved. The before and after images prove what is possible in only 15 to20 years.

paragraphs.name: a7fe
paragraphs.text: I am thinking of the Loess Plateau example that John Liu reported on in the early 2000s. In this region of China, an area of hundreds of square kilometres was transformed from arid eroding semi-desert, to lush terraces that are bioproductive with the springs coming back and the tree cover being permanent again — basically increasing the carbon content in the soil, drawing down carbon from the atmosphere, improving the bio-productivity of the area, improving the hydrology of the area, improving the amount of food that it generated and so on.

paragraphs.name: eade
paragraphs.text: These things are possible, and there are examples all over the world.

The way that life creates conditions conducive to life is by continuously experimenting with novelty, and so things keep changing. Our planet sits within larger systems as well, that also affect how the conditions on our planet change.

paragraphs.name: b865
paragraphs.text: There is no destination sustainability. There is no destination regenerative culture. It is a continuous community-based process of learning of how to adapt and how to respond creatively to change.

paragraphs.name: 929e
paragraphs.text: [00:20:13] Working regeneratively is to do so in ways that we enable people to discover their own essence, their unique contribution to making the system more vibrant and more vital and more valuable. But in all levels of value, not just in economic terms.
We all have to walk that path. That is what life is all about. To be adaptive, resilient and regenerative — responding to change.

paragraphs.name: a810
paragraphs.text: You can listen to the whole recording here:

paragraphs.name: 788a
paragraphs.text: This episode ON SURVIVAL features the voices of culinary curator Monika Kucia from Warsaw Poland, Daniel Christian Wahl, author of Regenerative Cultures, and Helena Norberg Hodge, author of Ancient Futures and founder of the NGO local futures.

paragraphs.name: 6c07
paragraphs.text: Nordic By Nature is a mindful podcast with a global perspective, inspired by the Norwegian philosopher Arne Naess, who coined the term Deep Ecology. Nordic By Nature is created for you to listen with your headphones.

paragraphs.name: 7e56
paragraphs.text: Culinary curator Monika Kucia from Poland talks about how she takes the ego out of food. Design Leader and author Daniel Christian Wahl discuss bio-regional development. The founder of the NGO Local Futures, Helena Norberg Hodge, discusses the benefits of ‘localisation.’

paragraphs.name: c8ed
paragraphs.text:
Nordic By Nature

paragraphs.name: 1adf
paragraphs.text: Daniel Christian Wahl — Catalyzing transformative innovation in the face of converging crises, advising on regenerative whole systems design, regenerative leadership, and education for regenerative development and bioregional regeneration.

paragraphs.name: b2ab
paragraphs.text: Author of the internationally acclaimed book Designing Regenerative Cultures
